title: 103_s1049
content:
The Act titled "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" recognizes the scientific and environmental significance of Lechuguilla Cave and other caves in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. It aims to protect these caves from adverse effects of mineral exploration and development. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS

Cave protection area refers to lands within a specified map area. Secretary means the Secretary of the Interior. Other terms have the same meaning as in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976.

SEC. 4. LAND WITHDRAWAL. The approximately 6,280 acres of public lands within the cave protection area are withdrawn from all forms of appropriation or disposal under public land laws. The lands are described on a map filed in April 1993. The Protection Area, established in April 1993, withdraws 6,280 acres of public lands from appropriation. The Secretary must publish a notice in the Federal Register with the legal description and map of the withdrawn lands. The Protection Area, established in April 1993, withdraws 6,280 acres of public lands from appropriation. The map and legal description of the withdrawn lands have the same force and effect as if included in this Act, with the Secretary able to correct errors. Copies of the map and legal description are available for public inspection. The public lands withdrawn are under management. The public lands withdrawn under the Protection Area established in April 1993 shall be managed by the Secretary through the Director of the Bureau of Land Management in accordance with relevant laws. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING LEASES. The Secretary shall not permit new drilling on valid mineral or geothermal leases within withdrawn lands to prevent adverse impacts on cave resources of Carlsbad Caverns National Park. The Secretary prohibits new drilling on valid mineral or geothermal leases within withdrawn lands to protect cave resources of Carlsbad Caverns National Park. This prohibition remains in effect until a decision is made on the drilling proposal in the Dark Canyon Environmental Impact Statement, or for 12 months after the enactment of this Act. During the prohibition period, the Secretary can seek agreements for termination of existing mineral or geothermal leases on withdrawn public lands. The Secretary can seek agreements to terminate geothermal leases on public lands to protect cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. The Secretary will take steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park if no agreement is reached regarding a lease termination. The Secretary will take steps to protect the resources of Carlsbad Caverns National Park and lands within the cave protection area, which may include acquiring the lands covered by the lease. Any acquired lands will be managed according to relevant laws. The Secretary will seek cooperation from the State of New Mexico and other parties owning lands within the cave protection area to enforce restrictions for the protection of Lechuguilla Cave and other resources of Carlsbad Caverns National Park. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL PROTECTION AND RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. The Secretary will take additional steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park based on relevant scientific analysis. Access limitations may be imposed to safeguard these resources. The Secretary may limit access to lands owned by the United States and prohibit removal of mineral, geological, or cave resources to protect significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. If existing laws are insufficient, the Secretary may take additional steps to safeguard Lechuguilla Cave and other important cave resources. The Secretary may inform relevant committees if additional authority is needed to protect significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. This Act does not affect the ability to seek compensation under other laws. The Act does not prevent seeking compensation under other laws, such as the Tucker Act.
